ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The fundamental grammatical rules of the language and how to form the present and past tense.

I learned not only how to speak some French, but how to do so confidently. Towards the end of the semester I recognized that I could hold conversations in French with my peers outside of class, and write cohesive stories and reflections.
This was a great intro to French; at the end of the course, I have a solid grasp of French grammar and can hold a basic conversation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course is very useful if you're looking to learn French that will be useful in everyday conversation. This course sets a very firm foundation if you plan to pursue French further. The professors are lovely and the small class size made for a conducive learning environment.
Sections meet every day, though, and there is homework every day so the time commitment is very high.

A strength is the variety of ways the content is presented. I enjoy learning through the video because it makes the concepts in class seem less abstract as we see them used and analyzed by French speakers. In the workbook, these concepts are elaborated on, and in class our conversations and lectures allow for clarification and further questions. A weakness of the course was at times the pace, since some weeks would have two chapters to cover and other would have one. Weeks with two chapters were harder to ask questions about since there was double the content.
It's taught entirely in French, which can be very confusing to learn.
This is a very fast-paced course, which is a strength in that you learn a lot of material. However, it can also be a challenge to cover multiple (dense) chapters per week.
The nature of the course is that it moves very quickly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are looking to learn French and are willing to put in the time and effort to do well in the class.

I would recommend French 110 to any student interested in French since it provides such a great understanding of not only the French language, but also culture, in just a semester. The teaching method is very effective for learning the language and gives students the ability to ask questions on the subjects they are interested in.
I would not take French unless you are already familiar with it and want to live in France.
I would definitely recommend this course: if you want a solid foundation in French and are prepared to do a lot of work, it's perfect.
I would let the student know that the workload is quite high, and that you only get out what you put in.
